patterns.title: Two Pointers
patterns.description: Efficiently solve array problems by using two pointers that move towards or away from each other.
useCases: Finding pairs in a sorted array that sum to a target value
Detecting cycles in a linked list
Removing duplicates from a sorted array
patterns.algorithmicBackground: The Two Pointers technique is often used to solve problems with O(n) time complexity instead of O(nÂ²). It works particularly well with sorted arrays or linked lists.

examples.title: Two Sum II - Input Array Is Sorted
examples.description: Given a sorted array of integers, find two numbers such that they add up to a specific target number.

examples.title: Remove Duplicates from Sorted Array
examples.description: Given a sorted array, remove the duplicates in-place such that each element appears only once and return the new length.

examples.title: Container With Most Water
examples.description: Given n non-negative integers representing the heights of bars, find two bars that together with the x-axis forms a container that holds the most water.

patterns.title: Sliding Window
patterns.description: Efficiently process consecutive subarrays or substrings of a specific size.
useCases: Finding the longest substring without repeating characters
Finding the maximum sum subarray of a fixed size
Finding the smallest subarray with a sum greater than a given value
patterns.algorithmicBackground: The Sliding Window technique is used to perform operations on a dynamic window in an array or string. It converts two nested loops into a single loop, reducing time complexity from O(nÂ²) to O(n).

examples.title: Maximum Sum Subarray of Size K
examples.description: Find the maximum sum of any contiguous subarray of size k.

examples.title: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters
examples.description: Given a string, find the length of the longest substring without repeating characters.

patterns.title: Binary Search
patterns.description: Efficiently find an element in a sorted collection by repeatedly dividing the search space in half.
useCases: Finding the first or last occurrence of an element
Finding the square root of a number
Finding the peak element in a bitonic array
patterns.algorithmicBackground: Binary Search is a divide and conquer algorithm that works on sorted data. It repeatedly divides the search space in half, achieving O(log n) time complexity instead of O(n) for linear search.

examples.title: Binary Search in Sorted Array
examples.description: Search for a target value in a sorted array.

patterns.title: Depth-First & Breadth-First Search
patterns.description: Traverse and search tree or graph data structures using recursive or queue-based approaches.
useCases: Finding the shortest path in an unweighted graph (BFS)
patterns.algorithmicBackground: DFS explores as far as possible along each branch before backtracking, often implemented recursively. BFS explores all neighbors at the present depth before moving to nodes at the next depth level, using a queue.

examples.title: DFS Tree Traversal
examples.description: Perform a depth-first traversal of a binary tree.

examples.title: BFS Tree Traversal
examples.description: Perform a breadth-first traversal of a binary tree.

patterns.title: Dynamic Programming
patterns.description: Solve complex problems by breaking them down into simpler overlapping subproblems.
patterns.algorithmicBackground: Dynamic Programming optimizes recursive algorithms by storing results of subproblems to avoid redundant calculations. It's applicable when a problem has optimal substructure and overlapping subproblems.

examples.title: Fibonacci Sequence
examples.description: Calculate the nth Fibonacci number efficiently.

patterns.title: Backtracking
patterns.description: Find all (or some) solutions to computational problems by incrementally building candidates and abandoning them when they fail to satisfy constraints.
patterns.algorithmicBackground: Backtracking is a general algorithm for finding all (or some) solutions to constraint satisfaction problems. It incrementally builds candidates and abandons a candidate as soon as it determines the candidate cannot be valid.

examples.title: Generate All Permutations
examples.description: Generate all possible permutations of a given array of distinct integers.
